abstract.p: In this article, a Neumann expansion Monte Carlo stochastic meshless point interpolation method (NMC-SMPIM) is developed to obtain the stochastic structural responses. Furthermore, an artificial immune genetic algorithm (AIGA) is embedded within the NMC-SMPIM to perform the structural reliability analysis to avoid some challenging problems including easy appeared precocity, low searching efficiency, and poor individual diversity. Numerical examples show that the results obtained by the AIGA algorithm-embedded NMC-SMPIM are accurate, and this method has advantages in analysis of responses and reliability of probabilistic structures with moderate variance coefficients.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In the stochastic mechanics field, when one designs astructural or mechanical system, it is important toanalyze the uncertainties in the system (e.g. random material properties [1–3], random geometrical parameters [4, 5], random loadings [6–8], random fracture [9, 10], etc.) to consider its reliability. Based on this consideration, advanced computational tools have to be used to provide a necessary computational framework for the analysis of structural response and reliability. Currently, the most popular method in this field is the stochastic finite element method (SFEM) [1–8, 11–14]. For example, the fatigue reliability of the gear teeth subjected to bending was analyzed by the SFEM [1]. Several approaches have been developed for the SFEM, including Monte-Carlo SFEM [15, 16], perturbation SFEM [17–19], Neumann expansion approach [20], Karhunen-Loeve expansion approach [21, 22], Galerkin's method [23], and second-moment method [5], to mention a few. However, the SFEM requires a structured mesh to perform the underlying finite element analysis. For a complex geometric configuration, it is usually difficult, expensive, and time consuming to construct a good structured mesh. This issue is further complicated if the solid mechanics problem involves a discontinuous change in the geometry of the domain during the analysis procedure (e.g. crack propagation in solids). Simulations of manufacturing processes involving large deformation, such as extrusion, moulding, and metal forming, are also difficult to the FEM today because it is not efficient to handle frequent remeshing and severe mesh distortion. Therefore, there is a considerable interest towards eliminating or greatly simplifying the meshing task.

In recent years, a set of meshfree or meshless methods [24–31] that do not require a structured mesh to discretize the spatial domain has been developed. These methods use new approximation theories, which allow the resultant shape functions to be constructed entirely in terms of arbitrarily placed nodes. Because no element connectivity data is needed in meshless methods, the structured mesh construction problem for the complex geometry that occurs in the FEM can now be avoided. However, most of current developments in meshless methods have so far focused on deterministic problems. Probabilistic models using meshless methods have not received much attention. Hence, stochastic analysis involving meshless methods provides a rich, relatively unexplored area for future research in stochastic structures [32–34] and reliability analysis [35].

In structural reliability analysis, the reliability index is an important measure of the probabilistic structural safety [36] and it is usually computed through an optimization procedure. Normally the iteration methods are employed to solve this optimization problem. Recently a genetic algorithm (GA)-based artificial immune genetic algorithm (AIGA) has been introduced for optimization [37–40]. The applications of the AIGA to engineering are promising [41, 42].

When the standard deviations of the stochastic variables are moderate, the Neumann expansion approach [20] can significantly reduce the computational cost and has been widely used in engineering applications. Based on the Neumann expansion Monte Carlo method (NMC) [20] and the meshless point interpolation method (MPIM) [28], a Neumann expansion Monte Carlo stochastic meshless point interpolation method (NMC-SMPIM) is developed in this article to predict the stochastic responses of structures. Furthermore, to perform the structural reliability analysis, the AIGA is embedded within the NMC-SMPIM to speed the optimization procedure, which is required for the reliability index computation.

The structure of this article is as follows. In Section 2, the MPIM is briefly introduced and the delta function property and unity partition property of the new shape function are emphasized. In Section 3, the weak form of the governing equations in solid mechanics is obtained through the variational approach. The MPIM is then applied to discretize the governing equations and a set of algebra linear equations is achieved. In Section 4, the NMC is applied to compute approximate solutions of the system equations. The general procedure of the NMC-SMPIM is then summarized in this section. In Section 5, a procedure based on the AIGA is proposed to compute the reliability index for structural reliability problems. Section 6 is dedicated to the numerical verifications of the methods and algorithms developed in this article. First, two numerical examples are provided to show the accuracy of the proposed NMC-SMPIM. By comparing the results of the NMC-SMPIM with those of SFEM, the accuracy of the NMC-SMPIM is verified. To show the efficiency of the AIGA embedded NMC-SMPIM on the structural reliability analysis, a one-dimensional (1D) beam problem and a two-dimensional (2D) gear problem are simulated. A good agreement is obtained between the results of the proposed method and the SFEM. Although only 1D and 2D examples are shown in this article, it is straightforward to extend the developed method to three-dimensional (3D) problems because meshless methods have been widely used for 3D structures. The conclusions are then provided in the last section.

sec.title: 5 AIGA FOR RELIABILITY ANALYSIS
sec.p: In structural reliability problems, the reliability index β is a very important measure of the probabilistic structural safety and different methods (e.g. second-order second-moment method) have been proposed to compute β [36]. For general structure with a non-linear limit state function and/or non-normal distribution variables, the reliability index β is the shortest distance from the origin to the limit state surface g(X) = 0 [36]. The point X* (on the limit state surface) related to this shortest distance is the most probable failure point, which is crucial in structural reliability analysis. When deterministic methods (e.g. second-order second-moment method) are used to compute β, iteration procedure has to be employed and the gradient matrix has to be computed in each iteration, which is very time consuming. To overcome this difficulty, some optimization procedure can be introduced to compute β by searching the shortest distance between the origin and the limit state surface. In this article, the so-called GA-based AIGA is used to solve the above optimization problem efficiently. The AIGA is a new intelligent optimization algorithm synthesized the artificial immune algorithm with the genetic algorithm [37]. This algorithm can avoid some common problems in the optimization methods such as computation of gradient, easy appeared precocity, low searching efficiency, and poor individual diversity [37].

When the AIGA is applied to the structural reliabilityanalysis, the antigen, the antibody, the affinity between antigen and antibody correspond to the objective function, the solution and the combination intensity between the solution and the objective function, respectfully. The flow of the AIGA algorithm for the NMC-SMPIM method is as follows:

Step 1: Recognize antigens: The immune algorithm recognizes the invasion of the antigens which correspond to the input data. In the optimization problem, the objective function is used as the antigens.

Step 2: Initialize antibody: The memory cells which correspond to the case database are activated to produce the antibodies which are effective to kill the antigens in the past. The existence of memory cells can accelerate the convergence of immune algorithm. If the antigens are new, the antibody population is generated randomly; otherwise, they are generated from the memory cells. Let the antibody population size be N.

Step 3: Compute affinities: The affinity axv means the combination intensity between antigen and antibody v. It is defined as axv = − β, where β is the value of the objective function (i.e. the reliability index). Assume there are N antibodies with M genes in the immune system, the information entropy Hj(N) of the jth gene is [40] (25)
where Pij is the probability that the ith allele is on the jth gene and nj is the number of alleles (i.e. different values) on the jth gene. The average information entropy can be summarized as (26)
The affinity between the antibodies v and w is definedas (27)
where H(2) is the information entropy of antibodies v and w.

Step 4: Proliferate antibodies: The antibodies which will perform the next optimization generation are proliferated by mutation and crossover with pre-determined probabilities. After that, some new antibodies are generated randomly in order to improve the differentiation of the population. After the proliferation, the population, which is also called as “proliferation antibody population”, is N + W, where W represents the population of newly proliferated antibodies.

Step 5: Suppress antibodies: The suppression of antibodies is performed in two steps. In the first step, the suppression is determined by the affinity axv between the antigen and the antibody: For any antibody v in the proliferation antibody population, if axv is less than the threshold T (T = min(ax1, ax2, ... axn), which means the minimum affinity in the previous population), the antibody is eliminated. In the second step, the suppression is determined by the concentration Cv of the antibody. For an antibody v in the proliferation antibody population, the concentration Cv is defined as: (28)
where S is the sum of the antibodies, η×max⁡(ayv,w)≤ayv,w∗≤max⁡(ayv,w), the concentration parameter 0 ≤ η ≤ 1. In our computation, η = 0.6 is used. First the concentration Cv for every antibody in the proliferation antibody population is computed. Then the antibody v which has the maximum Cv is eliminated. This procedure continues until the population size becomes N. After the two steps of suppression, the population is called as ‘suppression antibody population’. It is clear that the size of the suppression antibody population is N in every generation.
Step 6: Differentiate memory cells: The antibodies which have high affinities with the antigen are added to the memory cells.

Step 7: Check the termination criterion: The termination criterion used in this article is the maximum iteration number, which means the optimization procedure will only stop if the maximum iteration number is reached. If the iteration number is less than the maximum iteration number, go to (Step 3) and start another iteration.
Step 8: Select optimal solution: After the iteration stops, the antibody which has the maximum affinity with the antigen in the memory cells is selected as the optimal solution.

sec.title: 6 NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
sec.p:
To verify the NMC-SMPIM method proposed in this article, it is first applied to a 1D cantilever problem, in which a concentrated vertical load is applied to the free end of the cantilever (Fig. 1). The length of the cantilever L = 1 unit; its cross-section area A = 1 unit; the load P = 1.0 unit. The Young's modulus of the cantilever is a random variable E(x) = μE [1 + α (x)], whereμE=1 unit is its average value; α (x) is a random field with zero-average Gaussian (normal) distribution, whose self-covariance function is Γα(ξ)=σE2exp⁡(–|ξ|/bL). Here ξ represents the distance between the two points x and x + ξi; its standard deviation σE=1 unit; the parameter b = 1. When the NMC-SMPIM is applied to this 1D problem, 16 nodes are evenly distributed on the x direction of the cantilever. The background mesh is coincident with the nodes. A four-point Gaussian quadrature is used to obtain the integrations numerically. The NMC-SMPIM is used to simulate 500 samples. For every sample, the convergence criterion is the absolute difference of the displacement between two iterations (the critical value is set as 1×10−4 unit). The average and standard deviation of the displacement are computed and compared with the standard SFEM in Fig. 2 (the standard SFEM results are obtained by in-house C++ program). In the results, an excellent agreement is achieved for this 1D problem. Fig. 1
Cantilever beam with a concentrated vertical load at the free end
Fig. 2
The average (left) and standard deviation (right) of the displacement for the cantilever beam

In the second example, a 2D square plate is investigated. The boundary condition and the loading areillustrated in Fig. 3. The length of the square plate L = 1 unit; the evenly distributed load on theright edge p = 1 unit; the Poisson's ratio ν = 0.3. The Young's modulus of the plate is a random variable E(x) = μE [1 + α(x)], where μE=1 unit is its average value; α(x) is a random field with zero-average Gaussian (normal) distribution, whose self-covariance function is Γα(ξ)=σE2exp⁡[(|ξ1|b1L/|ξ2|b2L)] for the two points (x1, x2) and (x1 + ξ1, ξ2 + ξ2), in which its standard deviation σE=0.12 unit and the parameters b1 = 1 and b2 = 2. In the NMC-SMPIM, 7×7 nodes are evenly distributed on the square plate. The background mesh is coincident with the nodes for the sake of simplicity. The numerical integration is obtained by 8×8 Gaussian quadrature and 500 samples are computed. The absolute difference of the displacement between two iterations is still used as the convergence criterion, and the critical value is set as 1×10−4 unit. The average and standard deviation of the displacement are computed using the proposed NMC-SMPIM. In Table 1, the average and standard deviation of the horizontal displacement u and the vertical displacement v at locations A, B and C are compared with the results from the standard SFEM (the standard SFEM results are obtained by in-house C++ program). Again, excellent agreement is achieved for this 2D problem. From these two numerical examples, the accuracy of the proposed NMC-SMPIM is verified. Table 1.

Then the NMC-SMPIM is incorporated with the AIGA to investigate the structural reliability problems. In the first example, an evenly distributed load and a concentrated load are applied to a 1D beam with one end fully fixed and the other end simply supported (Fig. 4). The evenly distributed load q = 10 800 N/m and the coefficient of variation cv = 0.15; the concentrated load p = 637 000 N and cv = 0.15; the yield strength σs = 310 MPa; and cv = 0.12; ; and all variables follow normal distributions. The covariance of nodal loading is rij = 0.9. The limit state function of the reliability analysis is g(X) = σS − σ, where σ is the normal stress. There are 16 nodes evenly distributed on the x direction of the beam for the meshless simulation. Again the background mesh is coincident with the nodes and a four-point Gaussian quadrature is used to obtain the integrations numerically. Ten thousand samples are simulated using the NMC-SMPIM. The penalty factor is set as λ = 104. The average and standard deviation of the maximum normal stress at the midpoint of the beam, as well as the reliability index β and the reliability of the structure R are listed in Table 2 and they are compared with the results of the standard SFEM, the standard Monte Carlo method, and the classical genetic algorithm (GA) [43]. The results of the standard SFEM and the standard Monte Carlo method are obtained by the in-house C++ programs. If the results of the standard SFEM are regarded as ‘quasi’ exact, it can be found that both the NMC-SMPIM and the classical GA can get much better results than the standard Monte Carlo method, which imply that the introduction of an optimization method (i.e. the immune algorithm and the classical genetic algorithm) can improve the search result. In this example, the result from the NMC-SMPIM is better than the classical GA and this probably comes from the characteristics of the AIGA [37]. It is noted that the computation result from the AIGA is independent of the value of λ provided that λ ≥ 104. Table 2.

In the 2D example, the bending fatigue reliability of a standard spur gear is analyzed using the AIGA embedded NMC-SMPIM. The parameters of the spur gear are: number of teeth Z = 20, m = 1, mm, pressure angle α = 20°. The Young's Modulus E of the gear is 210 GPa. As to the root bending fatigue strength of the gear, the limit state function of the reliability analysis is g(X) = σS − σ, where σS is the fatigue limit; and σ is the normal stress. The basic random variables affecting the reliability of the root bending fatigue strength are assumed to be stochastically independent. The load P, the Poisson's Ratio v of the material and the fatigue limit σS are taken as the basic random variables. The mean and standard deviation of each random variable are listed in Table 3. The NMC-SMPIM model of the spur gear is shown in Fig. 5. The background mesh is chosen such that its nodes coincide with the meshless nodes. An 8×8 Gaussian quadrature is used for all cells. The NMC-SMPIM is employed to simulate 100 000 samples. The computed reliability index is β = 3.153 and the predicted bending fatigue reliability of the standard spur gear is R = 0.933. A good agreement is obtained between the results of the proposed NMC-SMPIM method and the SFEM [1], where R = 0.928 is obtained. The accuracy of the AIGA embedded NMC-SMPIM is then verified. Table 3.

sec.title: 7. CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this article, a NMC-SMPIM is developed to compute the responses of probabilistic structures in stochastic mechanics. To solve the optimization problem related to structural reliability analysis, a GA-based AIGA is embedded within the NMC-SMPIM. Compared to the widely used SFEM, the NMC-SMPIM developed here does not require any structured mesh to perform the underlying numerical simulation of the solid mechanics problem. The polynomial interpolation with delta function property is proposed so that the essential boundary conditions can be implemented directly as in the FEM. The Neumann expansion Monte Carlo method is employed to solve the system equations for every sample generated by Monte Carlo method. Furthermore, the AIGA is introduced to analyze the reliability of probabilistic structures to avoid some challenging problems including easy appeared precocity, low searching efficiency, and poor individual diversity. Numerical examples show that the results obtained by the AIGA embedded NMC-SMPIM are accurate and this method has advantages in analysis of responses and reliability of probabilistic structures with moderate variance coefficients. The potential application of the stochastic meshless method in 3D non-linear problems is promising. However, similar to other Monte Carlo based methods, computational cost is a main concern in the NMC-SMPIM and parallel computation is to be implemented in our future study.
